summary: This is a legal filing from the law firm Haddon, Morgan and Foreman on behalf of Ghislaine Maxwell, responding to the government's letter regarding her motions to suppress evidence. The defense argues against deferring resolution of the suppression motions until after trial, asserting that the government's vague assurances do not adequately protect Maxwell's constitutional rights and that an evidentiary hearing is necessary before the trial on non-perjury counts.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case, whose defense team is filing this response to argue for an evidentiary hearing on motions to suppress evidence before her trial.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom this letter is addressed, regarding the scheduling of evidentiary hearings and suppression motions.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman who signed the letter, representing Ghislaine Maxwell and arguing for pre-trial resolution of suppression motions.

persons.name: Chief Judge McMahon
persons.context: Mentioned as the judge whom the government allegedly misled in an ex parte proceeding to circumvent a civil protective order, which forms part of the due process violation claim.

events.title: Government's Letter Regarding Suppression Motions
events.description: The government filed a letter stating it did not intend to use materials subject to suppression motions in its case-in-chief for the non-perjury trial but reserved the right to use them for other permissible purposes under evidence rules.

events.title: Ex Parte Proceeding Before Chief Judge McMahon
events.description: Alleged event where the government misrepresented information to Chief Judge McMahon to circumvent a civil protective order via an ex parte subpoena, obtaining approximately 90,000 pages of material.

locations: Southern District of New York, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: The defense argues the government violated due process, the Fourth Amendment, the Fifth Amendment, and legal precedent by obtaining evidence through an ex parte subpoena after misleading a judge.
Approximately 90,000 pages of material were obtained by the government through the allegedly improper ex parte proceeding.

The defense insists an evidentiary hearing (akin to a Kastigar hearing) is necessary before trial to determine if evidence is tainted and to protect Maxwell's right to make an informed decision about testifying.

The government's letter stated it did not intend to use the suppressed materials in its case-in-chief but reserved the right to use them for impeachment or other purposes under evidence rules, which the defense contests.
